newsitem.title: SWEDEN: SCA says uncertainty remains for 1997.
newsitem.headline: SCA says uncertainty remains for 1997.

text.p: Swedish forestry company Svenska Cellulosa Aktiebolaget (SCA) said on Thursday that major uncertainty for pulp and paper price developments remained for 1997.
"The recovery is taking place from a low level at a slow pace. Major uncertainty remains for price developments surrounding pulp and recycling paper," SCA said in its results statement.
"Economic growth in Europe is expected to develop positively in 1997 athough the pace of recovery may be slow."
It said for its hygiene products division, good demand was expected to continue while sales of corrugated board would be lifted by increased industrial production in Europe.
"For newsprint and fine paper, volumes and prices are now stabilising. For the second half of the year there will probably be continued price increases," SCA said.
The group posted a profit of 3.57 billion crowns after net financial items for 1996, a 38 percent fall on 1995 results. Net sales eased to 55.41 billion crowns from 65.32 billion.
Consensus forecasts put the profit at 3.52 billion crowns.
A stronger Swedish crown wiped out some of the profit.
"Of the decline, 13 percent was attributable to the effects of the appreciation of the Swedish crown," SCA said.
SCA said its hygiene products showed continued strong volume growth and a stable margin trend.
Packaging, graphic paper and sawn timber products saw continued weak but stabilising earnings.
SCA said the business climate for the industry began to stabilise in the second half of 1996 after a period of weakening which began in mid-1995.
"A slowing was noted during the second half of the year when it was thought that the inventory rundown phase was largely complete," SCA said.
SCA said the number of orders received rose in the second half of 1996 and some limited price increases were possible.

"In the second half of the year...it was possible to increase prices, although to a limited extent, on such products such as pulp, liner and sawn timber, which are normally positioned early in the business cycle," SCA said.
After several unsuccessful attempts to increase them further, pulp prices stabilised at about $560 per tonne.
